importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date marks the start of construction on the East Wing of the White House, signaling a major structural change to the presidential residence under President Trump.
Trump first announced the ballroom project in July 2025, marking the initial public declaration of his plan for a new White House ballroom.
Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt made a statement in August 2025 about the project's cost and timeline, confirming key logistical and financial details.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Construction is expected to be completed before the end of President Trump’s term, which ends in January 2029, setting a clear project timeline.

keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump has initiated construction on the East Wing of the White House to build a new 90,000-square-foot ballroom, the first such structural change since 1948.
The project, estimated at $250 million, is claimed to be privately funded by Trump and private donors, with no cost to taxpayers.
The ballroom will seat up to 999 guests and is intended to replace current state dinner arrangements held on the White House lawns.
The East Wing, originally built in 1902 and previously used by the first lady’s office and for hosting foreign dignitaries, is being reconstructed without demolition of the main White House building.
The project has proceeded despite lack of formal approval from the National Capital Planning Commission, which is currently closed due to a government shutdown.
The project is being led by McCrery Architects and Clark Construction, with engineering support from AECOM.
Trump claims the new ballroom fulfills a long-standing presidential dream and will not interfere with the existing structure, while maintaining respect for historical architecture.

summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump has begun construction on the East Wing of the White House to build a new 90,000-square-foot ballroom, the first major structural change to the complex since 1948. The project, estimated at $250 million and claimed to be privately funded, aims to provide a large space for state dinners and diplomatic events, addressing long-standing complaints about the lack of suitable venues. Despite not receiving formal approval from the National Capital Planning Commission due to a government shutdown, construction has proceeded. The East Wing, historically used by the first lady and foreign dignitaries, will be reconstructed without demolition of the main White House building, though it is built directly over an emergency bunker. The project is being led by McCrery Architects and Clark Construction, with engineering support from AECOM. The new ballroom, with a seating capacity of up to 999 people, will be completed before the end of Trump’s term in January 2029, with offices temporarily relocated during the process.
title: What to know about Trump’s plan to build $250m White House ballroom
